awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Novel Relaxations for Cardinality-constrained  Optimization Problems with Applications in Network Interdiction and Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In many fields, such as telecommunication, logistics, and genetics, a decision-maker often prefers to find a solution, where only a fraction of potential resource assignments is selected. Such solutions are easier to interpret and implement, but they may be difficult to identify. Leveraging new structural results, the investigators develop new techniques to obtain high quality solutions to these types of problems. This project will apply these techniques to data analysis and network interdiction problems.  Network interdiction models have been successfully used to identify vulnerabilities in power and water systems, and to secure networked systems. Improved methods will help create better predictive models and yield tools to enhance national security. This research will also support training of graduate and undergraduate students and creation of pedagogical material.

This project seeks to develop new convex relaxation techniques that will lead to stronger relaxation bounds for cardinality constrained mathematical programs (CCMPs) and improve the convergence of generic and custom branch-and-bound codes for mixed integer nonlinear programs. Specifically, the researchers will (i) investigate bilinear formulations of cardinality requirements through the lens of the recently developed convexification procedures; (ii) focus on disjunctive relaxations previously introduced for linear relaxations of CCMPs, which can be used to generate cuts from any simplex basic solution that does not satisfy a cardinality constraint; (iii) develop cutting plane strategies that can generate convex hull descriptions devised from extensions of reformulation-linearization techniques; and (iv) utilize the concept of permutation-invariance to develop new formulations and relaxations for CCMPs arising in data analysis and models of various logical propositions. The project will also investigate the application of these results to the KKT formulation of network interdiction with asymmetric information.  The investigators will also make use of these improved relaxations in the development of heuristic and exact solution techniques for sparse principal component analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Optimization problems involving cardinality constraints and nonlinearities have pervasive applications in business, engineering, and science. Consider two examples. First, sparse PCA is a specialized statistical analysis technique used to reduce the dimension of multivariate data sets. This problem can be solved using a branch-and-bound methods, where the quality of relaxation (upper bound for a maximization problem) is a significant determinant of the algorithm's effectiveness. In our research, we developed new techniques to convexify permutation-invariant sets, which remain the same when variables are swapped with one another. An application of this result allowed us to develop significantly tighter relaxations for sparse PCA problems, which reduces the gap to optimality by 98% for medium sized problems. Second example is the network reliability problem where we analyze the resilience of network design and routing when a certain number of links fail. This problem can be written as a disjoint bilinear programming problem. We developed new and tight relaxations for network reliability, related these new relaxations to affine policies in robust optimization problems. We developed new techniques to identify the probability with which link failures will cause the network to exceed its capacity. In addition, we have developed finite branch-and-bound algorithms for disjoint bilinear programming problem.

 

The general class of optimization problems that cover these problem types is a factorable mixed-integer nonlinear program. These problems are optimization problems where nonlinearities can be recursively decomposed as a product or sum of univariate functions. We developed new relaxation techniques for composite functions which significantly improve over the typical relaxations used in mixed-integer nonlinear programming. Our relaxations close 60-70% of the gap on polynomial optimization test instances relative to factorable relaxations which are used in state-of-the-art solvers. These composite relaxations benefit from relaxations of multilinear functions over Cartesian products of simplices. We show that this problem is closely related to the problem where we choose variables so that a tree ensemble evaluates to the largest possible value. Tree ensembles is a common predictive modeling technique. Utilizing these insights we develop new relaxations for optimization problems involving tree ensembles. We also develop new relaxations for multilinear sets and show that these relaxations improve performance of current state-of-the-art solvers. These multilinear relaxations have now been included in the open-source solver ALPINE.
